description: The video satirically portrays the contradictory and victim-blaming societal messages directed at women regarding their safety and conduct, contrasting warnings about male behavior with dismissive attitudes when women express concerns or experience harm.

analysis: The video criticizes sexism by highlighting the double standards and societal pressures placed on women to manage male behavior and then dismissing their experiences or blaming them when they are harmed. It points out the prejudice against women based on gender stereotypes and the tendency to excuse male actions.

text: .....if we're dating i love "unconditionally"  red_heart  there never room for doubt if my woman doubts my love, tell me where i lack because you are a blessing. if there's doubt in our relationship, let's talk. i want to make you feel loved and not crazy. am i not giving you enough kisses? let me show you physical affection. tell me what i'm lacking and i'll fix it. i don't want you to doubt my love. you're not going anywhere. i involve you in everything, even wedding planning. where are you going? that's what i thought. trenzo tv.  if there's any space in my relationship where doubt comes into play, i'm not about to sit here and make her feel like she crazy, tripping you, tweaking you. no, communicate. what's wrong wrong what's going on talk to me is it because i'm not giving you enough kisses come here let me give you some kisses if i'm not touching you know, i don't love you. i don't want you to feel like, you know, you're not enough for me and stuff like that. because i'm going to tell you something. you're not going nowhere. i got a wedding that's planned out and involves you in it for it to work out so where you going? that's what i thought.
description: A man in a car discusses reassuring his partner if she doubts his love, starting with communication but ending with possessive statements like 'you not going nowhere' and referencing his pre-planned wedding involving her.
label: YES
analysis: The video embodies sexist attitudes through the speaker's possessive and controlling statements (e.g., 'you not going nowhere' with a 'STINK' overlay), which imply a lack of agency for his partner and reflect patriarchal notions of male dominance in relationships.

text: when animals attack; girls, boys.
description: The video contrasts reactions to animal attacks, showing a woman panicking and fleeing from a goose, labeled 'Girls', followed by several clips of men calmly or bravely confronting dangerous animals like cheetahs, an elephant, and a lion, labeled 'Boys'.
label: YES
analysis: The video promotes sexist gender stereotypes by depicting women as fearful and reactive in a mildly threatening situation, while portraying men as brave, composed, and capable when faced with genuinely dangerous animals. This contrast relies on and reinforces prejudiced beliefs about gendered behavior and capabilities.

text: "i need a man who's willing to defend me from other guys who hit on me."  i deserve it.
description: The video displays a quote attributed to a woman stating her desire for a man who would physically assault other men for flirting with her, followed by a young man looking in a mirror and then a clip of Will Smith.
label: YES
analysis: The video embodies sexism by promoting the harmful gender stereotype that women desire and require men to be violently possessive and act as aggressive protectors, reinforcing traditional notions of toxic masculinity and female dependency. The inclusion of Will Smith, known for a public act of aggression, potentially normalizes or even glorifies this problematic expectation without clear criticism.

text: replying to  our brains seek shortcuts all the time, but this one can lead to some harmful  very easily! “i don’t know” is better than “basketball” in this case. why can most people answer this question about a total stranger, and what does it mean?  every semester when i teach general psychology, i show people this man and i ask, does he play chess or basketball? and most people are able to answer one way or the other. in class most people tend to go with chess unless they're kind of contrarian or they think he's really tall and then they go with basketball the thing is i have no idea what this guy plays or doesn't play because this is a stock photo of a tall nerd from 2005. the same type of cognitive shortcut is responsible for people being able to make this judgment about this total stranger for people calling me karen online because i'm white, middle-aged and disagreed with somebody or for people currently debating what is the right representation of autism in autistic community. this shortcut is representativeness heuristic. this is when we match what we see to our existing mental prototype and make judgments based on that prototype. it's stereotyping and we do it a lot.
description: A woman explains the 'representativeness heuristic,' a cognitive shortcut leading to stereotyping, using an example of judging a man's hobbies based on his appearance and relating it to being called a 'Karen' due to her demographics.
label: YES
analysis: The video criticizes sexism by highlighting how the 'representativeness heuristic' can lead to gendered stereotypes, such as labeling a middle-aged white woman a 'Karen' for expressing disagreement, which is a form of prejudice based on gender stereotypes and beliefs about how women should behave.

text: the garden of earthly delights by hieronymus bosch, featuring lil nas x. if eve is not in your garden, you can clean it with thegaze5.  call me when you need, call me in the morning, i'll be on the way. call me when you want, call me when you need call me out by your name, i'll be on the way like mmm, mmm, mmm mmm, mmm i wanna sell what you're buying i wanna feel on your oh shoot a shot in your mouth while i'm riding
description: A TikTok video showing various detailed scenes from Hieronymus Bosch's painting "The Garden of Earthly Delights," featuring numerous nude figures, with the song "MONTERO (Call Me By Your Name)" by Lil Nas X playing and an initial text overlay "if eve ain't in you."
label: YES
analysis: The video arguably embodies sexist elements by using the "Eve" reference in its opening caption, which can invoke traditional and potentially negative gender stereotypes about women (e.g., as temptresses or inherently sinful). Additionally, the juxtaposition of sexually objectifying song lyrics with numerous images of nude female figures from the painting can contribute to the objectification of women, as the video does not offer a critical perspective on these elements.

label: NO
analysis: The video features a self-deprecating joke based on a misunderstanding of the word 'period'. It does not marginalize, express prejudice against women, promote male superiority, or contain misogynistic views, nor does it criticize sexism.

text:
gender identity ≠ sexual orientation  raising_hands_light_skin_tone  actual convo we had at pride event in 2019 
me  i think i'm the only heterosexual person here.
person  excuse me?
me  everyone here is lgbtq+.
person  oh, i see. i'm heterosexual but also part of the lgbtq+ community.
me  that's great, gender identity is separate from sexual orientation.
person  you're so right.
me  thank you for understanding, it's important to recognize that identifying as lgbtq+ doesn't automatically mean being gay.  i'm the only heterosexual person here. excuse me? everyone here is lgbtq+. i'm heterosexual and in the lgbtq community. my identity as a transgender woman is separate from my sexual orientation. you're so right. just because you're lgbtq plus doesn't mean you're gay. yeah, it's so easy to get confused, but i'm glad you understand. thanks for calling me in and not calling me out.
description: A man and a transwoman have a conversation at a Pride event where the man mistakenly assumes everyone LGBTQ+ is not heterosexual, and the transwoman educates him that gender identity and sexual orientation are separate.
label: NO
analysis: The video does not criticize or embody sexism; it focuses on correcting a misunderstanding about LGBTQ+ identities, specifically the distinction between gender identity (transwoman) and sexual orientation (heterosexual), in a respectful and educational manner.

text:
it's the small things, p.s these are only jokes chezaidan giving women compliments  "you look beautiful." 
chezaidan giving men compliments  "you're handsome."  wow, you're beautiful. oh, jeez, thanks. hey, i like your sweater. i will cherish this for the rest of my existence. i will die for you.
description: The video contrasts a stereotyped casual reaction of a woman receiving a compliment about her beauty with an exaggeratedly grateful reaction of a man receiving a compliment about his sweater.
label: YES
analysis: The video embodies sexism by relying on gender stereotypes: women are portrayed as receiving compliments so frequently (particularly on their appearance) that they become dismissive ('throws them with the rest'), while men are depicted as rarely receiving them and cherishing them intensely. This generalization about women's reactions can be seen as subtly prejudicial, implying they are unappreciative or jaded, thus reinforcing a gender stereotype.
